Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Virtual Organization Resources and Toolkits Exchange (VORTEX)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although many virtual organizations (VO) are quite effective, not all VO practitioners are effective in each area, and there is no organized body of knowledge or set of ?best practices? among VOs to draw upon for key issues. Therefore centers are likely not as effective as they could be. This proposal involves the creation of an online knowledge exchange. This Virtual Organization Resources and Toolkits Exchange (VORTEX) would provide leaders of virtual organizations with resources about running virtual organizations and access to relevant organizational scientists. VORTEX is intended to aid in building a community among virtual organization leaders so that they can collaborate, share, and learn with and from each other.

Specific Objectives of the work include development, evaluation, and improvement of an online Virtual Organization Resources and Toolkits Exchange (VORTEX) environment to aid scientists and engineers to more effectively lead virtual organizations. This type of environment is necessary in order to:
(1) Connect leaders of virtual organizations with appropriate organization scientists;
(2) Provide online educational and reference materials for issues associated with managing virtual organizations; and
(3) Establish a center for leaders of virtual organization to share and collaborate with each other.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Collaborative Research: Virtual Organization Resources and Toolkits Exchange (VORTEX) project translated and promoted the body of knowledge around the conduct of distributed science.  Just as many organizations now work with employees in different locations, scientific projects do as well, our project identified and publicized resources to help science work better.

The project disseminated these results through two websites.  The first is a curated a resource on "Collaborating Virtually" on an NIH funded site: https://www.teamsciencetoolkit.cancer.gov/

The second is the creation of the "Distributed Science" website at UT Austin: http://distributedscience.ischool.utexas.edu. Masters students from UT Austin, each on track to become an information professional, created guides targeted at helping practitioners quickly access knowledge. Our guides include, "Guides for planning and proposing projects" (such as choosing distributed collaboration technologies), "Guides for running your projects" (such as agendas for running virtual meetings), "Guides for communicating about and evaluating your projects" (such as "measuring impact"). Each guide links to existing curated research; not hundreds of articles but a handful together with estimates of reading time, because working scientists, just as others, don't have time to read all the literature out there, they want to get to work. The guides available on the website currently are:

    - Guide to Structuring Distributed Work
    - Guide to Types of Distributed Organizations
    - Guide to Choosing Distributed Collaboration Technology
    - Guide to Distributed Data Management Plans
    - Guide to Managing a Virtual Meeting
    - Guide to Managing an Online Community
    - Guide to Distributed Knowledge Management
    - Guide to Structuring Distributed Work
    - Guide to Finding Online Conversations About Distributed Science
    - Communicating Impact of Distributed Science 1: Value Propositions
    - Communicating Impact of Distributed Science 2: Measuring Impact

Working with our collaborators at Georgia, we produced a framework to different types of distributed organizations: from traditional employment hierarchies, work teams, open collaborations, and managed crowds. We also wrote about difficulties in changing between these different kinds of organizations. That work was published in Gregory, Berente, and Howison (2015) "Digital Technologies and Patterns of Distributed Innovation". We also published a book chapter summarizing knowledge on distributed work in a book about Team Science, Howison and Berente (2018) "Strategies for success in virtual collaboration".

We had planned to establish a membership clearinghouse for "expert exchange." but research showed this was in fact unlikely to work. Instead we identified existing venues for interaction and engagement on distributed science, such as Quora and Stack Exchange. We summarized these findings in our "Guide to Finding Online Conversations About Distributed Science." In short, they are promising venues but lack participation from senior scientists, we hope this will change over time.

We continue to work with our collaborators from UGA towards a meta-analysis of literature on online community participation, highlighting drivers of participation involving identification, commitment, and engagement with a community. We are also analyzing primary drivers of knowledge sharing in an online community: participation, social ties, and group identification with a community.
